Curriculum

The Open Curriculum for Learning Web Development

Roadmap

  1. Introduction
  2. About Web Developers
    1. What A Web Developer Does
    2. Web Development Jobs and Careers
    3. Tools of the Trade
    4. Web Development Communities
    5. The Best Web Developers
    6. Getting Hired as a Web Developer
    7. Finale
  3. Installations
  4. Pair Programming
    1. Why We Pair
    2. How To Pair
    3. A Sample Pairing Session
    4. Finale
  5. Web Development 101
    1. How Does the Web Work?
    2. How Does Your Computer Work?
    3. Terms to Know
    4. Web Programming Basics
      1. Front End Basics
        1. HTML and CSS Basics
        2. Project: HTML / CSS
        3. Javascript and jQuery Basics
        4. Project: JS and jQuery
      2. Back End Basics
        1. Ruby Basics
        2. Project: Ruby
      3. Databases
      4. Web Development Frameworks
        1. Ruby on Rails
        2. Project: Ruby on Rails
        3. Backbone.js
      5. Tying It All Together
      6. Additional Important Topics
    5. How are Websites Built?
    6. Principles of Good Programming
    7. Other "Dumb" Questions Answered
    8. Finish
  6. Ruby
    1. Basic Ruby
      1. Building Blocks
      2. Project: Building Blocks
      3. Advanced Building Blocks
      4. Project: Advanced Building Blocks
    2. Intermediate Ruby
      1. Object Oriented Programming
      2. Project: OOP
      3. File I/O and Serialization
      4. Project: File I/O and Serialization
    3. Ruby on the Web
      1. Project: Ruby on the Web
    4. Computer Science-y Ruby
      1. Recursion
      2. Project: Recursion
      3. Data Structures and Algorithms
      4. Project: Data Structures and Algorithms
    5. Testing Ruby with RSpec
      1. Project: Testing Ruby
    6. Ruby Final Project
    7. Finale

  13. Contributing

http://coding.smashingmagazine.com/2013/01/03/starting-open-source-project/

Contributor Anyone who has had source code merged into the repository is considered a contributor. The contributor cannot access the repository directly but has submitted patches that have been accepted. Committer People who have direct access to the repository are committers. These people work on features and fix bugs regularly, and they submit code directly to the repository. Reviewer The highest level of contributor, reviewers are commanders who also have directional impact on the project. Reviewers fulfill their title by reviewing submissions from contributors and committers, approving or denying patches, promoting or demoting committers, and generally running the project.


This is your curriculum so please make it better! Do you know a better link to high quality content or a better way to explain something? Would you like to write some exercises or projects to help students learn the material? How long did this section take you?
